what: Impute new unseen data using a saved imputer object
title: Imputing newdata with a saved mixgb imputer
text: demonstrate impute new data using saved imputer, first split newborn dataset training data test data. Next, impute training data using mixgb(). allows us generate m imputed datasets save corresponding imputation models setting save.models = TRUE. default, models variables missing values training data saved (save.vars = NULL). new unseen data may contain missing values additional variables, users can save models variables setting save.vars = colnames(train_data). can time-consuming, model needs trained saved variable. users confident certain variables missing values future data, efficient specify variables save.vars. save imputer object, specify local directory using save.models.folder argument mixgb(). backend, models saved JSON format via xgb.save(). approach, recommended XGBoost, preferred directly saving XGBoost models saveRDS() ensures compatibility future XGBoost releases. users specify save.models.folder, return object include following: imputed_data: list m imputed datasets training data XGB.models: list directories m sets XGBoost models variables specified save.vars. params: list parameters required imputing new data using impute_new() later . XGB.save : parameter indicates whether XGB.models saved models directories saved models. mixgb_obj contain models , users need worry saving object via saveRDS(). later use, one can load object R impute new data. impute new data saved imputer object, can use impute_new() function. Users can decide whether perform initial imputation new data. default, training data used impute missing values new dataset initially (initial.newdata = FALSE). step, missing values new data imputed using saved models imputer object. approach considerably faster, avoids retraining imputation models. predictive mean matching (PMM) used mixgb(), predicted values missing entries new dataset matched donors training data. Users can also specify number donors PMM. default setting pmm.k = NULL indicates pmm.k value training object inherited. Similarly, number imputed datasets new data can set via m impute_new(). value must less equal m used mixgb(). specified, impute_new() use m value stored saved imputer object.
code: set.seed(2026) n <- nrow(newborn) idx <- sample(1:n, size = round(0.7 * n), replace = FALSE) train_data <- newborn[idx, ] test_data <- newborn[-idx, ] # create a temporary folder tmp_folder <- file.path(tempdir(), "mixgb_models") dir.create(tmp_folder, showWarnings = FALSE)  # obtain m imputed datasets for train_data and save imputation models mixgb_obj <- mixgb(data = train_data, m = 5,                     save.models = TRUE, save.models.folder = tmp_folder)  saveRDS(object = mixgb_obj,          file = file.path(tmp_folder, "mixgb_imputer.rds")) mixgb_obj <- readRDS(file = file.path(tmp_folder, "mixgb_imputer.rds")) test_imp <- impute_new(object = mixgb_obj, newdata = test_data) test_imp <- impute_new(object = mixgb_obj, newdata = test_data) test_imp <- impute_new(object = mixgb_obj, newdata = test_data,                         initial.newdata = FALSE, pmm.k = 3, m = 4)

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: mixgb package provides scalable approach imputation large data using XGBoost, subsampling, predictive mean matching. leverages XGBoost—efficient implementation gradient-boosted trees—automatically capture complex interactions non-linear relationships. Subsampling predictive mean matching incorporated reduce bias preserve realistic imputation variability. package accommodates wide range variable types offers flexible control subsampling predictive matching settings. also recommend package vismi (Visualisation Tools Multiple Imputation), offers comprehensive set diagnostics assessing quality multiply imputed data.

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: first load mixgb package newborn dataset, contains 16 variables various types (integer/numeric/factor/ordinal factor). 9 variables missing values. impute dataset, use default settings. default, number imputed datasets set m = 5. data need converted dgCMatrix one-hot encoded format, transformations handled automatically package. Supported variable types include numeric, integer, factor, ordinal factor.
code: library(mixgb) str(newborn) #> tibble [2,107 × 16] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>  $ household_size                : int [1:2107] 4 3 5 4 4 3 5 3 3 3 ... #>  $ age_months                    : int [1:2107] 2 5 10 10 8 3 10 7 2 7 ... #>  $ sex                           : Factor w/ 2 levels "Male","Female": 2 1 2 2 1 1 2 2 2 1 ... #>  $ race                          : Factor w/ 3 levels "White","Black",..: 1 1 2 1 1 1 2 1 2 2 ... #>  $ ethnicity                     : Factor w/ 3 levels "Mexican-American",..: 3 1 3 3 3 3 3 3 3 3 ... #>  $ race_ethinicity               : Factor w/ 4 levels "Non-Hispanic White",..: 1 3 2 1 1 1 2 1 2 2 ... #>  $ head_circumference_cm         : num [1:2107] 39.3 45.4 43.9 45.8 44.9 42.2 45.8 NA 40.2 44.5 ... #>  $ recumbent_length_cm           : num [1:2107] 59.5 69.2 69.8 73.8 69 61.7 74.8 NA 64.5 70.2 ... #>  $ first_subscapular_skinfold_mm : num [1:2107] 8.2 13 6 8 8.2 9.4 5.2 NA 7 5.9 ... #>  $ second_subscapular_skinfold_mm: num [1:2107] 8 13 5.6 10 7.8 8.4 5.2 NA 7 5.4 ... #>  $ first_triceps_skinfold_mm     : num [1:2107] 9 15.6 7 16.4 9.8 9.6 5.8 NA 11 6.8 ... #>  $ second_triceps_skinfold_mm    : num [1:2107] 9.4 14 8.2 12 8.8 8.2 6.6 NA 10.9 7.6 ... #>  $ weight_kg                     : num [1:2107] 6.35 9.45 7.15 10.7 9.35 7.15 8.35 NA 7.35 8.65 ... #>  $ poverty_income_ratio          : num [1:2107] 3.186 1.269 0.416 2.063 1.464 ... #>  $ smoke                         : Factor w/ 2 levels "Yes","No": 2 2 1 1 1 2 2 1 2 1 ... #>  $ health                        : Ord.factor w/ 5 levels "Excellent"<"Very Good"<..: 1 3 1 1 1 1 1 1 2 1 ... colSums(is.na(newborn)) #>                 household_size                     age_months  #>                              0                              0  #>                            sex                           race  #>                              0                              0  #>                      ethnicity                race_ethinicity  #>                              0                              0  #>          head_circumference_cm            recumbent_length_cm  #>                            124                            114  #>  first_subscapular_skinfold_mm second_subscapular_skinfold_mm  #>                            161                            169  #>      first_triceps_skinfold_mm     second_triceps_skinfold_mm  #>                            124                            167  #>                      weight_kg           poverty_income_ratio  #>                            117                            192  #>                          smoke                         health  #>                              7                              0 # use mixgb with default settings imp_list <- mixgb(data = newborn, m = 5)

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: can also customise imputation settings: number imputed datasets m number imputation iterations maxit XGBoost hyperparameters verbose settings. xgb.params, nrounds, early_stopping_rounds, print_every_n verbose. Subsampling ratio. default, subsample = 0.7. Users can change value xgb.params argument. Predictive mean matching settings pmm.type, pmm.k pmm.link. Whether ordinal factors converted integer (imputation process may faster) ordinalAsInteger Initial imputation methods different types variables initial.num, initial.int initial.fac. Whether save models imputing newdata save.models save.vars.
code: set.seed(2026) # Use mixgb with chosen settings params <- list(   max_depth = 5,   subsample = 0.9,   nthread = 2,   tree_method = "hist" )  imp_list <- mixgb(   data = newborn, m = 10, maxit = 2,   ordinalAsInteger = FALSE,    pmm.type = "auto", pmm.k = 5, pmm.link = "prob",   initial.num = "normal", initial.int = "mode", initial.fac = "mode",   save.models = FALSE, save.vars = NULL,   xgb.params = params, nrounds = 200, early_stopping_rounds = 10, print_every_n = 10L, verbose = 0 )

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Imputation performance can influenced choice hyperparameters. tuning large number hyperparameters may seem daunting, search space can often substantially reduced many correlated. mixgb, function mixgb_cv() provided tune number boosting rounds (nrounds). XGBoost define default value nrounds, users must specify parameter explicitly. default setting mixgb() nrounds = 100; however, recommend using mixgb_cv() get appropriate value first. default, mixgb_cv() randomly selects incomplete variable response fits XGBoost model using remaining variables predictors, based complete cases dataset. result, repeated runs mixgb_cv() may yield different results. Users may instead explicitly specify response variable set covariates via response select_features arguments, respectively. can set nrounds = cv.results$best.nrounds mixgb() generate five imputed datasets.

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Older version mixgb package included visual diagnostic functions. now removed mixgb. recommend standalone package vismi (Visualisation Tools Multiple Imputation), provides comprehensive set visual diagnostics evaluating multiply imputed data. details, please visit: https://agnesdeng.github.io/vismi/ https://github.com/agnesdeng/vismi.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Yongshi Deng. Author, maintainer. Thomas Lumley. Thesis advisor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Deng Y, Lumley T (2024). “Multiple Imputation XGBoost.” Journal Computational Graphical Statistics, 33(2), 352-363. doi:10.1080/10618600.2023.2252501.
code: @Article{,   title = {Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost},   author = {Yongshi Deng and Thomas Lumley},   journal = {Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics},   volume = {33},   number = {2},   pages = {352-363},   year = {2024},   publisher = {Taylor & Francis},   doi = {10.1080/10618600.2023.2252501}, }

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: R package mixgb provides scalable approach multiple imputation leveraging XGBoost, subsampling predictive mean matching. shown method can yield less biased estimates reflect appropriate imputation variability, achieving high computational efficiency. details, see paper Multiple Imputation XGBoost.

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: New Development Version v2.1.3 GitHub - Jan 2026 Support saving intermediate imputation summary statistics can passed vismi package convergence diagnostics. New Release CRAN - Dec 2025 New CRAN version 2.0.3. Now compatible XGBoost (3.1.2.1) CRAN. update addresses breaking changes introduced latest XGBoost release CRAN December 2025. experience problem, please post issue GitHub.

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: can install development version mixgb GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("agnesdeng/mixgb") library(mixgb)

previous_headings: 2. Sanity check input data before imputation
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Please clean check data imputation. common issues: Data data frame. ID removed Missing values coded NA NaN Inf -Inf allowed Empty cells coded NA sensible values Variables “character” type converted “factor” Variables “factor” type least two levels

previous_headings: 2. Sanity check input data before imputation
what: Using check_data() for preliminary data check
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: function check_data() performs preliminary check attempts fix obvious issues. Step 1: data input needs data.frame, tibble data.table Step 2: convert character variables factor type stringAsFactors = TRUE Step 3: convert NaN, "NaN" NA Step 4: convert Inf, -Inf, "Inf", "-Inf" NA Step 5: convert empty strings "" NA Step 6: check factor variables single level ask user whether remove Step 7: check factor variables many levels (max_levels) ask user whether keep Return: preliminarily checked data, missing values encoded NA. Please note function serves reminder important data cleaning almost surely address data quality issues :)
code: bad_data <- newborn bad_data[, "ethnicity"] <- as.character(bad_data[, "ethnicity",     drop = TRUE]) bad_data[2, "ethnicity"] <- "NaN" bad_data[, "age_months"] <- as.factor(bad_data[, "age_months",     drop = TRUE]) bad_data[, 1] <- "" bad_data[, "sex"] <- "Unknown" bad_data[4, "weight_kg"] <- NaN bad_data[5, "weight_kg"] <- Inf  check_data(data = bad_data, max_levels = 10)

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Please read: https://agnesdeng.github.io/mixgb/articles/Using-mixgb.html

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: crucial assess plausibility imputations analysis. standalone R package vismi (Visualisation Diagnostics Multiple Imputation) provides comprehensive set diagnostics assessing quality multiply imputed data. package supports imputed data generated various multiple imputation methods, including mixgb, mice, . details, please check: https://agnesdeng.github.io/vismi/

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Multiple imputation can run GPU support machines NVIDIA GPUs. Users must first install R package xgboost GPU support.

previous_headings: 6. Install mixgb with GPU support > 6.1 Newest Version
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: XGBoost recently introduced breaking change. current mixgb release CRAN (≥ 2.0.3) compatible XGBoost 3.1.2.1. GPU support yet fully tested update. ’ll test GPU support update soon time.

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Please refer instructions older version want use GPU support mixgb.

previous_headings: 6. Install mixgb with GPU support > 6.2 Older Version
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Please download Newest version XGBoost GPU support via XGBoost GitHub Releases. users can install newest version package mixgb R. utilise GPU version mixgb(), users can simply specify device = "cuda" params list passed xgb.params argument function mixgb(). Note default, tree_method = "hist" XGBoost 2.0.0.
code: # Change the file path where you saved the downloaded # XGBoost package install.packages("path_to_downloaded_file/xgboost_r_gpu_win64_2.0.0.tar.gz",     repos = NULL) devtools::install_github("agnesdeng/mixgb") library(mixgb) params <- list(device = "cuda", subsample = 0.7, nthread = 1,     tree_method = "hist")  mixgb.data <- mixgb(data = withNA.df, m = 5, xgb.params = params)

previous_headings: 6. Install mixgb with GPU support > 6.2 Older Version
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: xgboost R package pre-built binary Linux x86_64 GPU support can downloaded release page https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/releases/tag/v1.4.0 package can installed running following commands: users can install package mixgb R. utilise GPU version mixgb(), users can simply specify tree_method = "gpu_hist" params list passed xgb.params argument function mixgb(). adjustable GPU-related arguments include gpu_id predictor. default, gpu_id = 0 predictor = "auto".
code: # Install dependencies $ R -q -e "install.packages(c('data.table', 'jsonlite'))"  # Install XGBoost $ R CMD INSTALL ./xgboost_r_gpu_linux.tar.gz devtools::install_github("agnesdeng/mixgb") library(mixgb) params <- list(max_depth = 3, subsample = 0.7, nthread = 1, tree_method = "gpu_hist",     gpu_id = 0, predictor = "auto")   mixgb.data <- mixgb(data = withNA.df, m = 5, xgb.params = params)

previous_headings: 6. Install mixgb with GPU support > 6.2 Older Version
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: multithreading, users can set XGBoost nthread parameter OpenMP support. advised, OpenMP support currently disabled MacOS.

title: Data cleaning — check_data
text: function `check_data()` serves purpose performing preliminary check fix evident issues. However, function resolve data quality-related problems.

title: Data cleaning — check_data
code: check_data(data, verbose = TRUE, max_levels = 50, stringsAsFactors = TRUE)

title: Data cleaning — check_data
text: data data frame. verbose Verbose setting. TRUE, print warnings data issues found. Default: TRUE. max_levels integer specifying maximum number levels allowed factor variables. Default: 50. stringsAsFactors logical value indicating whether character vectors dataset converted factors. Default: TRUE.

title: Data cleaning — check_data
text: preliminary cleaned dataset

title: Data cleaning — check_data
code: nhanes3[4, 4] <- NaN nhanes3[5, 5] <- Inf nhanes3[6, 6] <- -Inf  cleandata <- check_data(data = nhanes3) #>  #> ── Sanity Check ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> ! Numeric NaN values detected in `head_circumference_cm`. They have been converted to NA. #> ! Numeric Inf/-Inf values detected in `recumbent_length_cm` and `weight_kg`.They have been converted to NA.

what: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA
title: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA
text: function creates missing values missing complete random (MCAR) mechanism. demonstration purposes .

title: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA
code: createNA(data, cols = NULL, p = 0.3)

title: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA
text: data complete data frame. cols vector specifying names columns missing values generated. p proportion missing values data frame proportions missing values corresponding variables specified cols.

title: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA
text: data frame artificial missing values

title: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA
code: # Create 30% MCAR data across all variables in a dataset withNA.df <- createNA(data = iris, p = 0.3)  # Create 30% MCAR data in a specified variable in a dataset withNA.df <- createNA(data = iris, cols = c("Sepal.Length"), p = 0.3)  # Create MCAR data in several specified variables in a dataset withNA.df <- createNA(   data = iris,   cols = c("Sepal.Length", "Petal.Width", "Species"),   p = c(0.3, 0.2, 0.1) )

what: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params — default_params
title: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params — default_params
text: Auxiliary function setting default XGBoost-related hyperparameters mixgb checking xgb.params argument mixgb(). details XGBoost hyperparameters, please refer XGBoost documentation parameters.

title: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params — default_params
code: default_params(   device = "cpu",   tree_method = "hist",   eta = 0.3,   gamma = 0,   max_depth = 3,   min_child_weight = 1,   max_delta_step = 0,   subsample = 0.7,   sampling_method = "uniform",   colsample_bytree = 1,   colsample_bylevel = 1,   colsample_bynode = 1,   lambda = 1,   alpha = 0,   max_leaves = 0,   max_bin = 256,   num_parallel_tree = 1,   nthread = -1 )

title: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params — default_params
text: device Can either "cpu" "cuda". options please refer XGBoost documentation parameters. tree_method Options: "auto", "exact", "approx", "hist". Default: "hist". eta Step size shrinkage. Default: 0.3. gamma Minimum loss reduction required make partition leaf node tree. Default: 0 max_depth Maximum depth tree. Default: 3. min_child_weight Minimum sum instance weight needed child. Default: 1. max_delta_step Maximum delta step. Default: 0. subsample Subsampling ratio data. Default: 0.7. sampling_method method used sample data. Default: "uniform". colsample_bytree Subsampling ratio columns constructing tree. Default: 1. colsample_bylevel Subsampling ratio columns level. Default: 1. colsample_bynode Subsampling ratio columns node. Default: 1. lambda L2 regularization term weights. Default: 1. alpha L1 regularization term weights. Default: 0. max_leaves Maximum number nodes added (used tree_method = "exact"). Default: 0. max_bin Maximum number discrete bins bucket continuous features (used tree_method either "hist", "approx" "gpu_hist"). Default: 256. num_parallel_tree number parallel trees used boosted random forests. Default: 1. nthread number CPU threads used. Default: -1 (available threads).

title: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params — default_params
text: list hyperparameters.

title: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params — default_params
code: default_params() #> $device #> [1] "cpu" #>  #> $tree_method #> [1] "hist" #>  #> $eta #> [1] 0.3 #>  #> $gamma #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_depth #> [1] 3 #>  #> $min_child_weight #> [1] 1 #>  #> $subsample #> [1] 0.7 #>  #> $sampling_method #> [1] "uniform" #>  #> $colsample_bytree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bylevel #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bynode #> [1] 1 #>  #> $lambda #> [1] 1 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_leaves #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_bin #> [1] 256 #>  #> $num_parallel_tree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $nthread #> [1] -1 #>   xgb.params <- list(device = "cuda", subsample = 0.9, nthread = 2) default_params(   device = xgb.params$device,   subsample = xgb.params$subsample,   nthread = xgb.params$nthread ) #> $device #> [1] "cuda" #>  #> $tree_method #> [1] "hist" #>  #> $eta #> [1] 0.3 #>  #> $gamma #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_depth #> [1] 3 #>  #> $min_child_weight #> [1] 1 #>  #> $subsample #> [1] 0.9 #>  #> $sampling_method #> [1] "uniform" #>  #> $colsample_bytree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bylevel #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bynode #> [1] 1 #>  #> $lambda #> [1] 1 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_leaves #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_bin #> [1] 256 #>  #> $num_parallel_tree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $nthread #> [1] 2 #>   xgb.params <- do.call("default_params", xgb.params) xgb.params #> $device #> [1] "cuda" #>  #> $tree_method #> [1] "hist" #>  #> $eta #> [1] 0.3 #>  #> $gamma #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_depth #> [1] 3 #>  #> $min_child_weight #> [1] 1 #>  #> $subsample #> [1] 0.9 #>  #> $sampling_method #> [1] "uniform" #>  #> $colsample_bytree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bylevel #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bynode #> [1] 1 #>  #> $lambda #> [1] 1 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_leaves #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_bin #> [1] 256 #>  #> $num_parallel_tree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $nthread #> [1] 2 #>

what: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params compatible with XGBoost CRAN version — default_params_cran
title: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params compatible with XGBoost CRAN version — default_params_cran
text: Auxiliary function setting default XGBoost-related hyperparameters mixgb checking xgb.params argument mixgb(). details XGBoost hyperparameters, please refer XGBoost documentation parameters.

title: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params compatible with XGBoost CRAN version — default_params_cran
code: default_params_cran(   eta = 0.3,   gamma = 0,   max_depth = 3,   min_child_weight = 1,   max_delta_step,   subsample = 0.7,   sampling_method = "uniform",   colsample_bytree = 1,   colsample_bylevel = 1,   colsample_bynode = 1,   lambda = 1,   alpha = 0,   tree_method = "auto",   max_leaves = 0,   max_bin = 256,   predictor = "auto",   num_parallel_tree = 1,   gpu_id = 0,   nthread = -1 )

title: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params compatible with XGBoost CRAN version — default_params_cran
text: eta Step size shrinkage. Default: 0.3. gamma Minimum loss reduction required make partition leaf node tree. Default: 0 max_depth Maximum depth tree. Default: 3. min_child_weight Minimum sum instance weight needed child. Default: 1. max_delta_step Maximum delta step. Default: 0. subsample Subsampling ratio data. Default: 0.7. sampling_method method used sample data. Default: "uniform". colsample_bytree Subsampling ratio columns constructing tree. Default: 1. colsample_bylevel Subsampling ratio columns level. Default: 1. colsample_bynode Subsampling ratio columns node. Default: 1. lambda L2 regularization term weights. Default: 1. alpha L1 regularization term weights. Default: 0. tree_method Options: "auto", "exact", "approx", "hist". Default: "hist". max_leaves Maximum number nodes added (used tree_method = "exact"). Default: 0. max_bin Maximum number discrete bins bucket continuous features (used tree_method either "hist", "approx" "gpu_hist"). Default: 256. predictor Default: "auto" num_parallel_tree number parallel trees used boosted random forests. Default: 1. gpu_id GPU device used. Default: 0. nthread number CPU threads used. Default: -1 (available threads).

title: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params compatible with XGBoost CRAN version — default_params_cran
text: list hyperparameters.

title: Auxiliary function for validating xgb.params compatible with XGBoost CRAN version — default_params_cran
code: default_params_cran() #> $eta #> [1] 0.3 #>  #> $gamma #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_depth #> [1] 3 #>  #> $min_child_weight #> [1] 1 #>  #> $subsample #> [1] 0.7 #>  #> $sampling_method #> [1] "uniform" #>  #> $colsample_bytree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bylevel #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bynode #> [1] 1 #>  #> $lambda #> [1] 1 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0 #>  #> $tree_method #> [1] "auto" #>  #> $max_leaves #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_bin #> [1] 256 #>  #> $predictor #> [1] "auto" #>  #> $num_parallel_tree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $gpu_id #> [1] 0 #>  #> $nthread #> [1] -1 #>   xgb.params <- list(subsample = 0.9, gpu_id = 1) default_params_cran(subsample = xgb.params$subsample, gpu_id = xgb.params$gpu_id) #> $eta #> [1] 0.3 #>  #> $gamma #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_depth #> [1] 3 #>  #> $min_child_weight #> [1] 1 #>  #> $subsample #> [1] 0.9 #>  #> $sampling_method #> [1] "uniform" #>  #> $colsample_bytree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bylevel #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bynode #> [1] 1 #>  #> $lambda #> [1] 1 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0 #>  #> $tree_method #> [1] "auto" #>  #> $max_leaves #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_bin #> [1] 256 #>  #> $predictor #> [1] "auto" #>  #> $num_parallel_tree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $gpu_id #> [1] 1 #>  #> $nthread #> [1] -1 #>   xgb.params <- do.call("default_params_cran", xgb.params) xgb.params #> $eta #> [1] 0.3 #>  #> $gamma #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_depth #> [1] 3 #>  #> $min_child_weight #> [1] 1 #>  #> $subsample #> [1] 0.9 #>  #> $sampling_method #> [1] "uniform" #>  #> $colsample_bytree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bylevel #> [1] 1 #>  #> $colsample_bynode #> [1] 1 #>  #> $lambda #> [1] 1 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0 #>  #> $tree_method #> [1] "auto" #>  #> $max_leaves #> [1] 0 #>  #> $max_bin #> [1] 256 #>  #> $predictor #> [1] "auto" #>  #> $num_parallel_tree #> [1] 1 #>  #> $gpu_id #> [1] 1 #>  #> $nthread #> [1] -1 #>

what: Impute new data with a saved mixgb imputer object — impute_new
title: Impute new data with a saved mixgb imputer object — impute_new
text: Impute new data saved mixgb imputer object

title: Impute new data with a saved mixgb imputer object — impute_new
code: impute_new(   object,   newdata,   initial.newdata = FALSE,   pmm.k = NULL,   m = NULL,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Impute new data with a saved mixgb imputer object — impute_new
text: object saved imputer object created mixgb(..., save.models = TRUE) newdata data.frame data.table. New data missing values. initial.newdata Whether use information new data initially impute missing values new data. default, set FALSE, original data passed mixgb() used initial imputation. pmm.k number donors predictive mean matching. NULL (default), pmm.k value saved imputer object used. m number imputed datasets. NULL (default), m value saved imputer object used. verbose Verbose setting mixgb. TRUE, print progress imputation. Default: FALSE.

title: Impute new data with a saved mixgb imputer object — impute_new
text: list m imputed datasets new data.

title: Impute new data with a saved mixgb imputer object — impute_new
code: set.seed(2022) n <- nrow(nhanes3) idx <- sample(1:n, size = round(0.7 * n), replace = FALSE) train.data <- nhanes3[idx, ] test.data <- nhanes3[-idx, ]  params <- list(max_depth = 3, subsample = 0.7, nthread = 2) mixgb.obj <- mixgb(data = train.data, m = 2, xgb.params = params, nrounds = 10,                    save.models = TRUE, save.models.folder = tempdir())  # obtain m imputed datasets for train.data train.imputed <- mixgb.obj$imputed.data train.imputed #> [[1]] #>      age_months    sex        ethnicity head_circumference_cm #>           <int> <fctr>           <fctr> title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through 'XGBoost' — mixgb-package
text: Multiple imputation using 'XGBoost', subsampling, predictive mean matching described Deng Lumley (2024) doi:10.1080/10618600.2023.2252501 . package supports various types variables, offers flexible settings, enables saving imputation model impute new data. Data processing memory usage optimised speed imputation process.

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through 'XGBoost' — mixgb-package
text: Maintainer: Yongshi Deng agnes.yongshideng@gmail.com (ORCID) contributors: Thomas Lumley t.lumley@auckland.ac.nz [thesis advisor]

title: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — mixgb
text: function used generate multiply-imputed datasets using XGBoost, subsampling predictive mean matching (PMM).

title: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — mixgb
code: mixgb(   data,   m = 5,   maxit = 1,   ordinalAsInteger = FALSE,   pmm.type = NULL,   pmm.k = 5,   pmm.link = "prob",   initial.num = "normal",   initial.int = "mode",   initial.fac = "mode",   save.models = FALSE,   save.vars = NULL,   save.models.folder = NULL,   verbose = F,   xgb.params = list(),   nrounds = 100,   early_stopping_rounds = NULL,   print_every_n = 10L,   xgboost_verbose = 0,   ... )

title: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — mixgb
text: data data.frame data.table missing values m number imputed datasets. Default: 5 maxit number imputation iterations. Default: 1 ordinalAsInteger Whether convert ordinal factors integers. default, ordinalAsInteger = FALSE. Setting ordinalAsInteger = TRUE may speed imputation process large datasets. pmm.type type predictive mean matching (PMM). Possible values: NULL (default): Imputations without PMM; 0: Imputations PMM type 0; 1: Imputations PMM type 1; 2: Imputations PMM type 2; "auto": Imputations PMM type 2 numeric/integer variables; imputations without PMM categorical variables. pmm.k number donors predictive mean matching. Default: 5 pmm.link link predictive mean matching binary variables "prob" (default): use probabilities; "logit": use logit values. initial.num Initial imputation method numeric type data: "normal" (default); "mean"; "median"; "mode"; "sample". initial.int Initial imputation method integer type data: "mode" (default); "sample". initial.fac Initial imputation method factor type data: "mode" (default); "sample". save.models Whether save imputation models imputing new data later . Default: FALSE save.vars purpose imputing new data, imputation models response variables specified save.vars saved. values save.vars can vector names indices. default, imputation models variables missing values original data saved (save.vars = NULL). save imputation models variables, users can specify save.vars = colnames(data). save.models.folder Users can specify directory save imputation models. Models saved JSON format internally calling xgb.save(), recommended XGBoost. verbose Verbose setting mixgb. TRUE, print progress imputation. Default: FALSE. xgb.params list XGBoost parameters. details, please check XGBoost documentation parameters. nrounds maximum number boosting iterations XGBoost. Default: 100 early_stopping_rounds integer value k. XGBoost training stop validation performance improved k rounds. Default: 10. print_every_n Print XGBoost evaluation information every nth iteration xgboost_verbose > 0. xgboost_verbose Verbose setting XGBoost training: 0 (silent), 1 (print information) 2 (print additional information). Default: 0 ... Extra arguments passed XGBoost

title: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — mixgb
text: save.models = FALSE, function return list m imputed datasets. save.models = TRUE, return object imputed datasets, saved models parameters.

title: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — mixgb
code: # obtain m multiply datasets without saving models params <- list(max_depth = 3, subsample = 0.7, nthread = 2) mixgb.data <- mixgb(data = nhanes3, m = 2, xgb.params = params, nrounds = 10)  # obtain m multiply imputed datasets and save models for imputing new data later on mixgb.obj <- mixgb(   data = nhanes3, m = 2, xgb.params = params, nrounds = 10,   save.models = TRUE, save.models.folder = tempdir() )

what: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
title: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
text: Use cross-validation find optimal nrounds Mixgb imputer. Note method relies complete cases dataset obtain optimal nrounds.

title: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
code: mixgb_cv(   data,   nfold = 5,   nrounds = 100,   early_stopping_rounds = 10,   response = NULL,   select_features = NULL,   xgb.params = list(),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
text: data data.frame data.table missing values. nfold number subsamples randomly partitioned equal size. Default: 5 nrounds max number iterations XGBoost training. Default: 100 early_stopping_rounds integer value k. Training stop validation performance improved k rounds. response name column index response variable. Default: NULL (Randomly select incomplete variable). select_features names indices selected features. Default: NULL (Select variables dataset). xgb.params list XGBoost parameters. details, please check XGBoost documentation parameters. stringsAsFactors logical value indicating whether character vectors dataset converted factors. verbose logical value. Whether print cross-validation results process. ... Extra arguments passed XGBoost.

title: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
text: list optimal nrounds, evaluation.log chosen response.

title: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — newborn
text: dataset extracted NHANES III (1988-1994) age class Newborn (1 year). Please note example dataset contains selected variables demonstration purposes .

title: NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — newborn
code: data(newborn)

title: NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — newborn
text: data frame 2107 rows 16 variables, adapted NHANES III dataset. Nine variables contain missing values. Variable names factor levels renamed clarity easier interpretation. household_size Household size. integer variable ranging 1 10. original variable name NHANES III dataset HSHSIZER. age_months Age interview (screener), months. integer variable ranging 2 11. original variable name NHANES III dataset HSAGEIR. sex Sex subject. factor variable levels Male Female. original variable name NHANES III dataset HSSEX. race Race subject. factor variable levels White, Black, . original variable name NHANES III dataset DMARACER. ethnicity Ethnicity subject. factor variable levels Mexican-American, Hispanic, Hispanic. original variable name NHANES III dataset DMAETHNR. race_ethinicity Combined race–ethnicity classification. factor variable levels Non-Hispanic White, Non-Hispanic Black, Mexican-American, . original variable name NHANES III dataset DMARETHN. head_circumference_cm Head circumference, centimetres. Numeric. original variable name NHANES III dataset BMPHEAD. recumbent_length_cm Recumbent length, centimetres. Numeric. original variable name NHANES III dataset BMPRECUM. first_subscapular_skinfold_mm First subscapular skinfold thickness, millimetres. Numeric. original variable name NHANES III dataset BMPSB1. second_subscapular_skinfold_mm Second subscapular skinfold thickness, millimetres. Numeric. original variable name NHANES III dataset BMPSB2. first_triceps_skinfold_mm First triceps skinfold thickness, millimetres. Numeric. original variable name NHANES III dataset BMPTR1. second_triceps_skinfold_mm Second triceps skinfold thickness, millimetres. Numeric. original variable name NHANES III dataset BMPTR2. weight_kg Body weight, kilograms. Numeric. original variable name NHANES III dataset BMPWT. poverty_income_ratio Poverty income ratio. Numeric. original variable name NHANES III dataset DMPPIR. smoke Whether anyone living household smokes cigarettes inside home. factor variable levels Yes . original variable name NHANES III dataset HFF1. health General health status subject. ordered factor levels Excellent, Good, Good, Fair, Poor. original variable name NHANES III dataset HYD1.

Numeric. original variable name NHANES III dataset BMPHEAD. recumbent_length_cm Recumbent length, centimetres. what: Show multiply imputed values for a single variable — show_var

text: Show m sets imputed values specified variable.

title: Show multiply imputed values for a single variable — show_var
code: show_var(data, imp_list, x, true_values = NULL)

title: Show multiply imputed values for a single variable — show_var
text: data original data missing data. imp_list list m imputed datasets returned mixgb imputer. x name variable interest. true_values vector true values (known) missing values. general, unknown.

title: Show multiply imputed values for a single variable — show_var
text: data.table m columns, column represents imputed values missing entries specified variable. true_values provided, last column true values missing values.

title: Show multiply imputed values for a single variable — show_var
code: #obtain m multiply datasets library(mixgb) imp_list<- mixgb(data = nhanes3, m = 3)  imp_head <- show_var(imp_list = imp_list, x = "head_circumference_cm",   data = nhanes3)

title: mixgb 2.2.3
text: data_clean() now becomes check_data(). function performs preliminary sanity check imputation. checks added. arguments’ names changed show_var() function compatibility vismi package. dataset nhanes3_newborn replaced newborn, variables renamed clarity align vismi package. Variable names nhanes3 updated maintain consistency newborn.

title: mixgb 2.1.3
text: save.models = TRUE mixgb(), return object now includes mean variance imputed values variable iteration. allow users plot convergence diagnostics using package vismi.

title: mixgb 2.0.3
text: CRAN release: 2025-12-07

title: mixgb 2.0.3
text: global variable warning resolved

title: mixgb 2.0.2
text: Removed support bootstrap mixgb()

title: mixgb 2.0.2
text: num_class now passed params list, need set num_class=NULL non-multiclass imputation.

title: mixgb 2.0.2
text: Refactored mixgb_null() function better readability maintainability - using helper functions impute_each.R. relevant functions updated later.

title: mixgb 2.0.1
text: Removed macOS-specific -framework Accelerate flag Linux builds Makevars file ### related XGBoost Parameter Changes num_class now passed params list. remove reshape = TRUE argument predict() function deprecated XGBoost >= 2.0.0.

title: mixgb 2.0.0
text: package now compatible XGBoost version 3.1.1.1 higher. ### Related XGBoost Parameter Changes watchlist changed evals objective eval_metric now passed params list. convert data sparse.model.matrix xgb.DMatrix format. Note, quick fix minimal safe change, plan optimise data handling future releases. best.nrounds now obtained via cv.train$early_stop$best_iteration instead cv.train$best_iteration.

title: mixgb 1.5.3
text: CRAN release: 2025-04-06

title: mixgb 1.5.3
text: Cause error: scenario, Mis.m (matrix incomplete variables except currently imputed one) 0x0 matrix, caused error binding.

title: mixgb 1.5.2
text: CRAN release: 2024-12-02

title: mixgb 1.5.2
text: Significantly faster imputation optimising data preprocessing use RcppArmadillo Visual diagnostic functions moved vismi package Update Documentation

title: mixgb 1.4.2
text: Ensure feature matrix number columns feed XGBoost

title: mixgb 1.4.1
text: Compatible XGBoost >=2.0.0 CRAN version XGBoost (=1.7.5.1)

title: mixgb 1.4.1
text: Correct feature type numeric integer variable initial imputation Update save_yhatobs() Type 1 pmm.

title: mixgb 1.4.0
text: Significantly faster imputation optimising data preprocessing use RcppArmadillo Enhanced memory efficiency -place modifications using data.table Bootstrapping option removed mixgb(). Users can still use bootstrap archived function mixgb0(). PMM now set NULL default.

title: mixgb 1.3.2
text: Improves package documentation regarding import xgb.save() xgb.load() XGBoost.

title: mixgb 1.3.1
text: Introduces new parameter device. Deprecates parameters gpu_id predictor. Sets tree_method = "hist" default, aligning XGBoost 2.0.0.

title: mixgb 1.3.1
text: Models save JSON format using xgb.save(), method recommended XGBoost future compatibility. save.models.folder specified, return object mixgb() includes current imputed datasets, directories imputation models, relevant parameters. object can save using saveRDS() doesn’t directly contain models. Users can later load object R employ impute_new(object, newdata, ...) new data imputation.

title: mixgb 1.2.1
text: Includes URL published article.

title: mixgb 1.2.0
text: numeric integer factor logical Note: Users must manually convert character variables factors.

title: mixgb 1.1.0
text: Introduces default_params(), auxiliary function mixgb(), validate list XGBoost hyperparameters supplied user. simplifies hyperparameter modifications without requiring explicit specification default values.

title: mixgb 1.1.0
text: Addresses issues related PMM multiclass variables. Replaces ..density.. after_stat(density) plot_hist(). Replaces ..prop.. after_stat(prop) plot_bar().

title: mixgb 1.0.2
text: CRAN release: 2023-02-16

title: mixgb 1.0.2
text: Adjusts examples use nthread = 2 comply CRAN policies.

title: mixgb 1.0.1
text: Subsampling: subsample = 0.7. bootstrapping: bootstrap = FALSE.

title: mixgb 0.1.1
text: Resolves minor issue createNA() function. ordinalAsInteger: Changes TRUE FALSE. max_depth: Changes 6 3. nrounds: Changes 50 100. bootstrap: Sets TRUE default.

title: mixgb 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-06-07

title: mixgb 0.1.0
text: First version releases CRAN. Supports single multiple imputation. Offers customisable settings bootstrapping predictive matching. Provides visual diagnostics multiply imputed data.

title: mixgb 0.1.0
text: Mac OSX users might face challenges multithreading mixgb xgboost requires OpenMP multi-core operations. details, please refer OpenMP Mac.
